section.title: Adding an Object Storage Daemon (OSD) Node
section.para: To begin, make sure you have one or more baremetal servers that meet the minimum hardware requirements for an object storage daemon (OSD) node, as documented in the FIXME: broken external xref.
Ensure that disks designated to be used for the OSD data and journal storage meet the conditions below. If they do not, Ceph configuration will fail:

listitem.para: Any existing partitions must be deleted
The disk should not be mounted
The disk should not be in use or held by some other device

section.bridgehead: Adding an Object Storage Daemon (OSD) Node
section.para: The following steps will show you how to add a new OSD node to your servers.yml file and then run the playbooks that update your cloud configuration. You will run these playbooks from the lifecycle manager.

listitem.para: Log in to your lifecycle manager.
Checkout the site branch of your local git so you can begin to make the necessary edits:

In the same directory, edit your servers.yml file to add the details about your new OSD node(s). You can simply copy and paste the section for an existing server with the OSD-ROLE role and edit the values to match the new server being added.
For example, if you already had a cluster of three OSD nodes and needed to add a fourth one, you would add the details for your new OSD node to the bottom of the file in this format:
listitem.screen: # Ceph OSD Nodes - id: osd4 ip-addr: 192.168.10.9 role: OSD-ROLE server-group: RACK1 nic-mapping: MY-2PORT-SERVER mac-addr: 8b:f6:9e:ca:3b:78 ilo-ip: 192.168.9.9 ilo-password: password ilo-user: admin
listitem.para: You can find detailed descriptions of these fields .

important.para: You will need to verify that the ip-addr value you choose for this new node does not conflict with any other IP address in your cloud environment. You can confirm this by checking the ~/helion/my_cloud/info/address_info.yml file on your lifecycle manager.

listitem.para: In your control_plane.yml file, in the section that details the OSD server-role, you will need to check the values for member-count, min-count, and max-count, if you specified them, to ensure that they match up with your new total node count. For example, if you had previously specified member-count: 3 and are adding a fourth OSD node, you will need to change that value to member-count: 4. Note that these values are optional and may or may not be specified in your control_plane.yml file. If the values are not specified, proceed to Step 5.
Add the new node into Cobbler:
Then you can image the node:
listitem.screen: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml -e nodelist=<node name>

note.para: If you don't know the <node name> of your new OSD node, you can get it by using sudo cobbler system list

listitem.para: Before proceeding, you may want to take a look at ~/helion/my_cloud/info/server_info.yml to see if the assignment of the node you have added is what you expect. It may not be, as nodes will not be numbered consecutively if any have previously been removed. This behavior is by design, and is intended to prevent loss of data; the configuration processor retains data about removed nodes and keeps their ID numbers from being reallocated. See the Persisted Server Allocations section in for information on how this works.
Run the following series of playbooks to complete the deployment of your additional OSD node(s) to your Ceph cluster:
listitem.screen: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml --tags "generate_hosts_file" ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml --limit <hostname>
